HOME > Departments

Tax Collection

The Tax Collector is responsible for the collection of all taxes and fees for the City of Bayonne.

All questions regarding tax bills, due dates on tax bills, and outstanding delinquencies should be directed to this office.

View Computed Tax Rates for The City of Bayonne

All tax bills that are not delinquent may be paid online. First time users must register in order to use our online payment system. Please click on the link below and choose the option Create a New Account. If you are already registered, choose Sign in to account.

Online Tax Payments

Online Tax Inquiry

Note: This log-in is for TAXES ONLY ...or you can pay your property taxes at any branch office of Bayonne Community Bank.

New Jersey Division of Taxation Property Tax Relief Program

Featured Article

Tax Sale Notice

Posted Wednesday, March 5, 2025

TAX SALE NOTICE
of real estate in the
CITY OF BAYONNE
hudson county, new jersey
for non-payment of taxes and related municipal liens
public notice is hereby given
that i, ROSEMARIE N. MARTINEZ-KUFTA, collector of taxes for the
CITY OF BAYONNE
county of hudson
WILL SELL AT A PRIVATE SALE
on
Wednesday, APRIL 16, 2025

In the Office of the Tax Collector, 630 Avenue C, Bayonne, New Jersey, at 4:30 PM prevailing time, or at such other time and place to which said sale may then be adjourned, the following lands in the City of Bayonne, County of Hudson and State of New Jersey, more particularly described by block and lot numbers as designated in the Extended Tax Duplicate of the City of Bayonne now in use, for the amount of municipal liens shown below that are charged against each of the said lands respectively.

TAKE NOTICE, that the amounts shown include only property taxes and related liens chargeable against the hereinafter described lands as of December 31, 2024 including interest and costs calculated to the date of the sale in accordance with Title 54, Revised Statutes of the State of New Jersey, as amended and supplemented by Ch. 75, PL 1991.

TAKE FURTHER NOTICE, that said lands will be sold subject to redemption at 18% per annum.  The payment for the sale shall be made before the conclusion of the sale.

Industrial properties may be subject to the Spill Compensation and Control Act (N.J.S.A. 58:10-23 et seq.), the Water Pollution Control Act (N.J.S.A. 58:10A-1 et seq.), and the Industrial Site Recovery Act (N.J.S.A. 13:1K-6 et seq.).  In addition, the municipality is precluded from issuing a Tax Sale Certificate to any prospective purchaser who is or may be in any way connected to the prior owner or operator of the site.

Any properties for which there are no purchasers shall be struck off and sold to the City of Bayonne for redemption at the rate of 18% per annum.  All sales are subject to taxes, assessments, and other municipal liens from January 1, 2024.

At any time before the Sale, the Tax Collector will remove from the sale any property upon payment IN FULL of all lienable amounts due.  Property owners are put on notice that the amount required to save the properties from Tax Sale may be more than the amounts shown below.  Partial payments will not be accepted for removal from the Tax Sale.  Payment must be in the form of CASH, OR CERTIFIED CHECK.
 
                                                                                                                                 ROSEMARIE N. MARTINEZ-KUFTA, CTC
                                                                                                                                 TAX COLLECTOR

View Official Notice Here

Featured Article

Bayonne Third Quarter Property Taxes Due by Grace Date of Thursday, August 10

Posted Tuesday, August 1, 2023

The Bayonne Tax Collector’s Office announced that third quarter property tax payments are due on Thursday, August 10. The nominal legal due date for the tax bills was Tuesday, August 1.  The City Council authorized a grace period through the close of business on Thursday, August 10.  Payments made by that date will avoid a late fee.  Property owners may pay their taxes by mail or in person at City Hall, 630 Avenue C, or at Bayonne branches of BCB Bank, or online through the City of Bayonne website, www.bayonnenj.org. 

By state law, quarterly payments received after the close of business on Thursday, August 10, will incur interest charges dating back to Tuesday, August 1, the nominal, legal due date for the third quarter.  For anyone making payment in person on August 10, the Tax Collector’s Office strongly recommends paying in person at City Hall before the close of business that day at 4:30 p.m.  You can pay at the Tax Collector’s Office.

Those who handle their property taxes through their monthly mortgage payments should have received advice copies of the property tax bills in the third quarter tax mailing.  They should continue paying their property taxes through their mortgages.

The third quarter tax bill is an estimated one, because Hudson County did not set a 2023 tax rate before the bills were mailed.  This estimated bill has the same status as a regular tax bill and may be paid without interest through Thursday, August 10, the date specified as the end of the grace period. 

A final, reconciled tax bill for the year will be issued to taxpayers prior to Wednesday, November 1, 2023.  

Read Less Read More
Featured Article

Bayonne Second Quarter Property Taxes Due by Grace Date of Wednesday, May 10

Posted Monday, May 1, 2023

The Bayonne Tax Collector’s Office announced that second quarter property tax payments are due on Wednesday, May 10, 2023. The nominal legal due date for the tax bills was Monday, May 1, 2023.  The City Council authorized a grace period through the close of business on Wednesday, May 10, 2023.  Payments made by that date will avoid a late fee.  Property owners may pay their taxes by mail or in person at City Hall, 630 Avenue C, or at Bayonne branches of BCB Bank, or online through the City of Bayonne website, www.bayonnenj.org.

Featured Article

Bayonne Third Quarter Property Taxes Due by Grace Date of Wednesday, August 10

Posted Tuesday, August 9, 2022

August 9, 2022

The Bayonne Tax Collector’s Office announced that third quarter property tax payments are due on Wednesday, August 10. The nominal legal due date for the tax bills was Monday, August 1.  The City Council authorized a grace period through the close of business on Wednesday, August 10.  Payments made by that date will avoid a late fee.  Property owners may pay their taxes by mail or in person at City Hall, 630 Avenue C, or at Bayonne branches of BCB Bank, or online through the City of Bayonne website, www.bayonnenj.org. 

By state law, quarterly payments received after the close of business on Wednesday, August 10, will incur interest charges dating back to Monday, August 1, the nominal, legal due date for the third quarter.  For anyone making payment in person on August 10, the Tax Collector’s Office strongly recommends paying in person at City Hall before the close of business that day at 4:30 p.m.  You can pay at the Tax Collector’s Office.

Those who handle their property taxes through their monthly mortgage payments should have received advice copies of the property tax bills in the most recent tax mailing.  They should continue paying their property taxes through their mortgages.

Featured Article

Rosemarie Martinez Named Tax Collector for the City of Bayonne

Posted Friday, February 19, 2021

At its meeting on February 17, the Bayonne City Council approved Mayor Jimmy Davis’s nomination of Rosemarie Martinez to serve as Tax Collector for the City of Bayonne.  She will assume the office effective March 1, 2021 for an initial period through December 31, 2021, and then for a four-year term effective January 1, 2022 through December 31, 2025.  Ms. Martinez will replace Interim Tax Collector Kenneth Bosotina.  The last permanent Tax Collector was Joanne Sisk, who served from 2002 until her retirement in 2019.  Ms. Martinez has worked in the Tax Collector’s Office since July 2019 with the title of Assistant Tax Collector.  As she prepared to assume the title of Tax Collector, Ms. Martinez said, “I am grateful to Mayor Davis and the City Council for this once-in-a-lifetime opportunity.” Mayor Davis said, “The City of Bayonne is happy to have a Tax Collector who is already a highly experienced professional in government service.  From her years in county and municipal government, Rose is very familiar with economic development, municipal finance, and the other issues that we face. We wish Rose the best as she begins this new period of service to the people of Bayonne.”

View Additional Information Here
